You got a few xp, a few golds to buy not too useful stuff on the city and almost no story in between to connect the locations in some meaningful story.

KINDA SPOILER ALERT.
We were so disappointed that opened all boxes to look what's that treasures we were haunting for (opening it is one of the prize you get for accomplishing the heroe's mission). And you know what? The art is amazing and we expected some really powerful races to fight against the demons army and found... The same stuff you have initially. Just different beautiful art. Extremely overrated.
Let's start with the good things
- The setting has some pretty interesting fluff. The various species in particular are unique and interesting. Some of the classes are also pretty original.
-The art is marvellous.
-The little secrets are interesting, it's a shame they ALL revolve around cryptology though.

Now the strongest outliers for how bad the game is:
-The tactics are extremely dull: the strongest plays are always to alpha strike as many enemies as you can before they counter.
-The design space overall is narrow AND the game is too badly balanced to actually make good use of that narrow space: block and retaliate are bad choices 90% or more of the time.
-It's stretching those few possibilities into so few classes that it doesn't become about depth of strategic choice but about bypassing constraints, such as that new bannerspear class that does the same thing pretty much everyone else does, but requires specific ally placements to do it. Plenty of skills are traps as well, most of upgrade choices for your skill deck are between a trap of a card (like double loss cards) and a good but boring one.
-Neither the double card gimmick and the element gimmick bring intereting choices to the table. You end up playing the same cards together the whole time once you figure your good actions out, and anyone decent at tactics figures it out pretty much from the get go, which is inexcusable for a game with that lifespan, it makes the core gameplay loop extremely dull and repetitive.
-For a game that prides itself on story, the character writing is nonexistent, there's more characterization in the retired events than everywhere else.
-The claim about it being an "ever-branching story" are utterly false. If a sprout goes away from the trunk to come right back into it, it's not much of a branch; and the game only includes something like 4 of those fake branches in the whole core campaign? The rest is about which order you choose to do those in. If a video game RPG was called everbranching when whoever you side with in punctual events doesn't affect the ending, it would be a lie. The same applies here.
-There some mechanics that both feel bad and whose thematic justifications are utterly insane, the best example being able to loot enemy corpses in plain sight in the middle of combat while your buddies are fighting for their lives, and when you end up with a comparatively insane amount of loot doing that over and over, you somehow can't share it, and you're supposed to believed that the other grizzled adventurers won't mug you for being selfish while they risked their lives.

Overall, the whole thing is at once a shallow and extremely repetitive experience. The game benefitted from some expert marketing and a massive bandwagon effect, and its continued success is justified by a denial stemming from sunk cost fallacy, simple materialism and peer pressure. Surprisingly, Founders of Gloomhaven is actually a good game, and gets shafted because it disappoints the fools that may buy it trying to feed their gloomhaven addiction and end up with a game that actually requires analytic skill.

Edit: Forgot to mention that there's no excuse for such a convoluted AI. Those can be justified if they provide to a game with great strategic depth, Gloomhaven is no such game.

Gloomhaven is a relatively engaging and gamey implementation of a dungeon crawl that treads new ground rather than relying on familiar mechanics like 20 sided dice. The story creates a side veneer of interest that propels character advancement and investment in the proceedings but the whole thing would be overwrought and uninteresting without the core card play mechanic.

Said card system is both the strength and weakness of this game as a whole. It creates a puzzly situation each turn where you have to think through optimum play for both now and the future while also trying to take into account what the monsters are going to do (semi-random) and what your team is going to do (contextual on good communication and teamwork). The system does make for more interesting decisions than most dungeon crawlers, but the reliance that the system creates on effective teamwork is both good and bad in that it requires a fully invested, pretty cooperative team all on the ball to really hum as it is challenging enough to require that level of engagement, even with lower level monsters the inherent nature of the card play requires several steps of look ahead and makes this a fairly challenging game to play competently.

I admire the design, as having this quantity of legacy material work, with the sheer number of player classes, all of the abilities, and so forth is quite an impressive feat. This base game is quite difficult to get into cold, as the game has no real introductory scenarios. For that, you need to check out the later Jaws of the Lion box which plays similarly but has a slimmed down campaign with less legacy but way better intro rules.

Aside: you want spin down monster token holders (for HP tracking). It speeds play a lot. Having initiative round tracking markers (which are included in Jaws of the Lion, but not here due to the number of monster classes) is also a big gameplay aid. Even with those, this thing is fiddly to set up and play in terms of the physical stuff you're dealing with and keeping track of.

Final assessment: I like the idea of this, but the implementation leaves me dissatisfied. All of the issues of slow combat in D&D are exacerbated here by the straight jacket that the card system puts on everything that you do in game. I find it odd that the most challenging thing in this game often ends up being just having the ability to move enough to effectively take your combat actions.

While this gamey puzzle element is undoubtedly what the fans love about it, I find it obnoxious in practice; as so much of it is reliant on the team working together and a single action taken by one player can have negative cascading effects on the other players because of how actions are selected at the start of the round. Hence, optimal play would be the living hell of alpha player dictating actions to the team. Not having some table talk would make this impossible to be successful in though, so it ends up trying to split the baby with the suggestions in the rules (which effective amount to: table talk, but in general terms only) that try to obscure this core issue. I think I would have ultimately enjoyed this game a lot more if initiative was a separate roll or mechanic from the actions and players were allowed to just choose their actions when their turn comes up. Having movement not being tied to the cards would also likely have improved my enjoyment of it as well. The existing system is moderately more elegant, but it makes the play pretty dissatisfying to me and some of the players we may have otherwise enjoyed this game with.

At the end of the day, this takes the thing I dislike most about post 3.0 D&D (endless array of special powers you have to keep track of and combo with each other like a video game) and ports it into a puzzley board game that makes that the whole shebang. It's not a bad design per se, but it's not for me and I don't care to play it again. My ratings ultimately reflect how much I want or would be willing to play it, not its "objective" quality, hence the 2.

Easily the most disappointing gaming experience I ever had. What represents itself as the grandest dungeon crawler of all time with a lush story filled with choices is really just the same hand management efficiency puzzle over and over again complicated by a massive setup, teardown and admin ask from the user. Despite the lifetime of content and the supposed weight on BGG, it offers a very thin experience in terms of player choice. In my experience the dunegon is a puzzle that doesn't really have very many options for how to solve it due tot he exhaust mechanic where you must complete the dungeon before you run out of cards. This turns every scenario into a math problem where you must pre-calculate every move you plan on taking for the rest of the game, lest you find yourself thinking you're crushing the enemy only to find out hours and hours later that you don't have enough cards left to win. Complicating matters are the imperfect information you have as the player by way of unopened rooms and the modifier deck which serve to throw even the most accurately calculated plan out the window. It's just terrible game design, that masks itself in a robust amount of content.

If BGG tracked the plays of the folks that praise this game to the ends of the earth, I would estimate that the average amount of plays is less than 10 out of the over 100 scenarios in the game.

I really wanted this to work, but after pushing myself through a full, honest 15 scenarios looking for anything to keep me on the hook, I just had to accept that the whole experience was pretty miserable.

As has been said by so many others, the setup and teardown is prohibitively time consuming, and even a short session requires so much bookkeeping on the part of the game owner that the widespread description of Gloomhaven being a DM-less experience feels disingenuous at best.

Enemy AI manages to be both error-prone and dumb. You would think that a system opaque enough to spawn a challenging fan-made online quiz would produce less robotic and less exploitable enemy behavior during combat. It's almost like the role of Dungeon Master or a robust digital AI system is necessary for meaningful enemy tactics in games like this...

The combat modifier deck feels like a downgrade to custom dice or a bag of tiles (ala Arkham Horror LCG) for seemingly no other reason than to give players the illusion of less randomness, but with the added headache of constant reshuffling.

The exhaustion/recovery system is needlessly frustrating and weirdly unthematic, and it is the only real source of difficulty in the whole game. Hoarding cards during the early portions of a scenario is crucial to ensure your character doesn’t become prematurely exhausted, but this means that most scenarios consist of hours and hours of piddling around with Move 2 / Attack 2 effects until you get to the last room and can actually start have fun playing the cards that make your class compelling. Gloomhaven makes no effort to emphasize the importance of this scenario cadence in the rules, and learning it yourself through several three hour delayed player eliminations early on is a vicious, depressing waste of time.

The plot is paper thin and the writing is shockingly cliché for how original the world seemed from the outside. The campaign is also pretty unresponsive to scenarios being done out of the "intended" order; random characters that the party hasn't met yet will pop in and out of story segments, only to later be "introduced" to the party after circling back to their branching scenario path. I get that this stuff is harder to get right in a physical medium (a recurring theme for Gloomhaven), but it shouldn't be this blatant.

The treasure looting system also breeds an unhealthy amount of tacit hostility with your "teammates"; treasure is individually gained and cannot be shared, and for some reason that has never made any thematic sense the mercenaries cannot pick up any coins or open any chests on their way out of a now-empty dungeon at the end of a scenario. The system incentivizes tactical greed, but all it takes is one overly-greedy move by a player to cost the whole group a scenario that may have already eaten up hours of playtime, and the only solution offered by the game would be to restart and try again from the beginning. Gross. For this reason I am convinced that Gloomhaven, like so many other coops, only really works as a solo game.

Considering that, why am I paying over a hundred dollars for a solo dungeon crawler that pales in comparison to even the most middling video games in this genre?

I come from a background of computer RPG games of the likes of Baldur's Gate and I can see how someone not familiar with those games, can find this game thrilling but if you like the idea of turn based combat, leveling up your character and progressing in a story, a boardgame is just not the ideal medium to do that, or at the very least, Gloomhaven is certainly not the ideal way to do that. RPG video games just do that so much better.

Once we get past the mountains of bookkeeping and maintenance around Gloomhaven, all that is left is a repetitive and unbalanced card management game. The core of the gameplay is simply looking through your deck of abilities and execute rules mindlessly. You can't be too strategic and plan ahead and you also can't take risks because the attack modifier is just too unpredictable for you to create any meaningful and reliable strategy.

Having to look through your deck is frustrating, having to operate the enemies is annoying, having to keep track of the damages and debuffs is excruciatingly annoying and finicky. Having to populate rooms once you walk into them midway through the game is anti-climatic and also annoying. Between all the ability decks and attack modifier decks you might end up with literally 15 different decks laying around on the table, are you kidding me?

The ability deck mechanic in this game is completely flawed and just creates a false sense of strategy and options when in the majority of cases, you are always shoved into a corner with one, maybe two actually correct plays to make. I can come up with multiple better ideas in how to force a rotation among abilities better than simply having you lose the card for the scenario simply because it was a good ability. What happened to the dude in a thematic sense? did he forget how to cast a spell? It's a ridiculous mechanic. Perhaps an ability point system could have been used, with better cards costing more AP and not as powerful cards costing less AP. The same exact end result would have been achieved without the demented discard and lost piles. The concept of mana or energy could have also been utilized instead, with powerful cards costing more mana, which then could have been recovered through resting. Again, same end result without cumbersome and constant deck fiddling.

The setup, storing and overhead management of this game is ridiculous (to note that I even bought the Broken Token insert!). All the different decks that need to be managed and stored, with certain attack modifiers being added only in certain scenarios which then need to be removed. Ability decks that get changed and updated. Everything is so cumbersome and it adds nothing to the gameplay itself.

Ultimately, despite my best efforts, I struggle to find a single thing about this game that is fun or well designed. Even the components and artwork is uninspired and mediocre at best. I can also understand why to so many, this seems like a fantastic game. It's the perfect game for gamers who like to be guided into a decision rather than having multiple real options. It's easy, it's comforting and offers that sense of reward and gratification common to role playing games which again, if that's what you crave, try playing some PC RPG games, they scratch that very same itch, times 10. Or, if you are looking for a great co-op boardgame, with meaningful decision-making and a legacy component that actually changes and evolves the gameplay itself, then try Pandemic Legacy.

I can see why some people like it*, but within about the first 60 seconds of rules explanation, I could tell it was aggressively not my kind of thing. (The difficulty of the first mission was perfect, though: we played on "normal" or whatever, 4-player, and won with one player down in a heroic sacrifice & two others one turn from croaking. My complaint is that the fundamental mechanic of the game--choose two cards, use the top of one & the bottom of the other, discard until you rest--is bogo-thematic. (As is the "standing-there-doing-nothing causes you to get fatigued enough to become a casualty just as fast as sprinting-around-getting-in-melee" mission clock.) (So is the Loot action, and loot in general.) And, coming from playing a lot of Dungeon Degenerates, "I will hit Generic Mook #9 for 3" was a lot less fun than "I will be in guard stance and hit the Sex Dwarf with my bastard sword," and the way the generic mooks' hit points get tracked seemed pretty clunky, too; "how many hit points does this guy have left" was like a 4-step process.

* That said, I can't see why it dominated the Golden Geeks, other than that it was A) an expensive Kickstarter game with B) miniatures and C) consumable elements. The character & dungeon map art is fine--nothing special--but the main environment map art is real bad.

This game was a huge disappointment. I cannot understand the throngs of people who praise this game. Leaving aside the weird, NPC-type character races (your choices are quite limited up front) and the badly-organized box (its half-assed attempt to provide some sort of organizational structure for the myriad decks of cards is insulting), my problem with this game comes down to the opening scenario. To say it is brutally difficult is an understatement. It is downright impossible. Changing strategies, characters, skill/spell loadouts, all yielded fast, frustrating death, if not in the first room, soon upon entering the second room of three. Forget trying to meet the (randomly-generated and very, VERY odd character goals) for the scenario. You'll need to seriously ratchet down the difficulty, beyond what the game even allows, basically house-ruling a way to win the first scenario. IE, the only way to win that first scenario is to cheat. What a fun way to play a game.
After running into loss after loss on the first scenario, I boxed this game up, sold it, shipped it, and never looked back.
There is no reason for a game to punish players who have just started. It's bad game design. A well-designed game can teach as it goes, introducing players to the complexities of gameplay as it progresses. A dedicated gaming group will not tolerate a game that dishes out constant losses, no matter how good it might get later on. There will be the inevitable responses of "get gud," etc, but a game has to have a hook to draw gamers in. This has only disappointment and frustration at the outset. Gloomhaven is not a well-designed game, no matter what may come later on.

If there's one thing I can say about Gloomhaven, it's that this game is ambitious... very ambitious. It's probably the most ambitious dungeon crawl adventure game I've ever played... and I'm not saying that as an accomplishment.

Gloomhaven is like combining D&D with filling out your income tax returns, except you have to use cardboard disks to do all your calculating instead of a calculator. This game combines elements from different genres into a Frankenstein's Monster of dungeon crawl action. I've never been more bored playing a game than during our introduction to Gloomhaven.

The only fun we had during the intro scenario were the few moments of levity we extracted out of the shared misery of painstakingly referencing and re-referencing the rules for the overly complicated combat mechanics over the course of two masochistic hours. We spent more time saying "what the hell does this card do?" and trying to keep track of who had what initiative than we did resolving anything that actually progressed the game to a conclusion.

This is the Star Wars prequels of adventure games. You're force-fed a vision of what an adventure is supposed to be like with none of the fun of an adventure. Your decision tree revolves around poorly designed cards that often resulted in our players just moving two spaces and punching a guy because that was often better than the abilities printed on the card... or maybe they didn't, I really don't know what the rest of my group was doing most of the time because I was so bored after spending an hour killing six Bandits that I checked out. I honestly don't know how this dumpster fire of a game got published and I sure can't fathom how it climbed so high on this website.

This is what happens when a game doesn't go through a traditional design process; conceptually this game is fantastic, in practice it's every idea one man ever had thrown into a single box and fused into something resembling a game. "No" is not a dirty word and this game would have been a lot better if someone had learned to say it at any point in the design process.

Gloomhaven has some great card strategy and deck building elements, but it is initially very slow and suffers from repetitiveness. I initially did not like my first few games due to overly simple plots, set up time, and limited variety in play. The story and strategy grew on me, but over time I would call this game samey in a way that many will hate. There's also very little story for a legacy game. You basically just fight over and over, which is really puzzle solving. There are a plethora of scenarios to play, but they are predictably samey. Get in quick, kill, and repeat.

Setup and teardown are extremely long. An organizer for setup and tear down is a good investment, else you'll have to dedicate the table for a while. You can only slightly deck-build compared to LCGs, but there's decent variety between the characters. There are enemy AIs, but again, many feel samey. The narrative is less hit than miss, which is unfortunate, but an imaginative group can add a lot with a little role-play.

The worst part of the game is the grind; unlocking cards, new characters, and equipment is very slow compared to many games. Slowly the prosperity allows new characters to start at higher levels, but even that is too slow. I don't see how people don't complain more about this! I house rule that you gain one level per game and double the income, and it still feels slow.

The brilliant part of this game is the ability to control the balance of the game no matter the number of or level of players; so you can easily get this to the table more than most campaign games. Similar to Mage Knight, there are times where players may have dozens of choices and slow the course of play, so best player count varies.

I don't really care for the art, the lack of art on the cards, or the programming that can waste cards just because someone else takes your action first. I'm also getting annoyed with rushing through every quest just to fit the way the card management works. It didn't bother me at first, but when you realize that you're going to repeat a dungeon, and you still have to finish out the play for the experience points, it becomes tedious to me. I'm glad this game exists, but surprised at the ratings, because this is a grind!

So as my rating would suggest, I am not on the Gloomhaven bandwagon. I cannot fault the ambitious scope of the game (if you love it, this game is fantastic value for money) but I find little in the gameplay that I enjoy. This is almost certainly connected to my own biases, as I can recognise there is certainly a good game inside Gloomhaven's giant box, but it's not the game for me.

Gloomhaven feels mechanically disconnected from its theme. I certainly wouldn't consider it the highly 'thematic' game (it's high 'thematic rank' on BGG annoys me more than anything else about the game). What is meant to be dynamic fantasy combat maybe a few minutes in length is simulated by slow, considered card play that takes place over hours. My decisions felt more strategic than the cut and thrust of skirmish combat. Tactical decisions on which card to play need to account for longer-term strategic goals, as powerful cards are often lost from the deck once played. This makes the game ponderous, as each player decides how to best solve the puzzle in front of them using the resources they have available. I enjoy both tactical and strategic thinking in games (see my highly rated games), but prefer that be married to themes that feel strategic (wargames representative of multi-year conflicts for example).

Where my biases are specifically relevant to my feelings on Gloomhaven are that I love tabletop roleplaying games. So much so that I was involved in running RPG conventions, have played over a hundred different systems across multiple genres and enjoy reading the rules and splat/world books in my spare time. But....there is one aspect of roleplaying I have never enjoyed. I dislike the classic Dungeons and Dragons dungeon crawl (DC). A DC, in my experience, is more about solving a puzzle and displaying rules knowledge than getting into character and generating a collective narrative. In fact, I've often said..'if you want to play a DC, why not just play a boardgame?' I guess I've now played that board game and realised I don't really like that either. The boxed text for Gloomhaven reminds me of all the parts I hate about DnD pre-written modules, with their 'on rails' plotlines and almost irrelevant backstory (who cares about the villain's goals...we're just going to kill them regardless).

The caveat to all of this is that I have only played a small number of missions. But I saw nothing in those missions that makes me want to ever play the game again. I'd much rather play a simpler dungeon-crawler, where the gameplay may have less depth, but where the game feels more dynamic and fast-paced. Clearing one room should not take 2-3 hours!

I could go on at *great* length about the things I don't like about Gloomhaven, but there's already mountains of opinion so I'll keep this reasonably short. I find the game to be thematically nonsensical, the story to be tedious and forgettable, and the combat to be a dull, static puzzle that rewards planning complete, optimal solutions over active turn-by-turn play.

I find it obnoxious that the basic combat mechanic is "taking actions takes away your actions." Failure usually has nothing to do with whether your characters are defeated in combat, or whether you faced overwhelming odds and made actual poor choices, but whether you successfully optimized.

Then there are the actions themselves. Imagine D&D where your wizard's spell either "does 4 radiant damage and you fall prone OR turns lead to chocolate and you move 5 feet". There's nothing to relate these things except that you have to choose between them. This is how every Gloomhaven card works. The effect is to make the game purely puzzle solving, and all theme and story is dispensable. They do nothing for each other. You're not "fulfilling your quest". You're prioritizing your resources in advance and then taking an hour to see if you optimized properly.

This game was a disappointment for my group. Granted, if you like the core puzzle, there is a lot of content, but our group did not find it particularly engaging. There are several compounding issues:
1) Setup and general management of components is time-consuming and clunky. Constantly shuffling decks and teardown/setup adds way too much overhead to actual game ratio.
2) Rules for cooperation/competition with your team feel floaty and obnoxious. The idea that you can only vaguely hint at what timeframe your action plays slows down the game and doesn't feel satisfying- we are aware there are rules for allowing full action information with your teammates, but the developers stress this is not the intended way to play the game.
3) Core combat puzzle is OK. We played 4 missions, and never felt like we were in a really tough spot or made really great moves; the system didn't feel like it lent itself to those sorts of plays. When things weren't looking our way, it was frequently because of a string of bad card draws from one of our players, leading more to a feeling of annoyance rather than feeling like we had more to learn in the system. It reminded me a lot of D&D combat in this way.
4) Story felt like typical fantasy and didn't grip us. We went to a LAVA MOUNTAIN and felt bored- something was wrong. Again, I'm sure there was more interesting plot development down the road, but the game failed to pull us into its narrative. The decisions we made along the road didn't feel interesting, and seemed to come from the Fable school of morality (e.g, do you want to steal this guys stuff while he takes a leak, or be friendly).

Lastly, I want to say that people aren't wrong from enjoying this game, or that there isn't fun to be had. We just feel there are games with a better core combat puzzle, and while the legacy format adds a lot, to us it just feels like a slog through the overuse of this puzzle; if you want to know a game we have a high opinion of in the combat-puzzle space, Mage Knight is one of our favorite games.

Simply put, this is a game with an OK combat puzzle and tons of content, but it does not deserve it's number one spot for so long, and we have no desire of playing it again.

If you combined together the best card mechanics from Gloomhaven and Mage Knight, supplied one hundred properly sculpted miniatures and presented the campaign set in an engaging non-generic universe then I’d be inclined to feel engaged in the game experience. The game is crunchy in terms of its weight. There is more complexity imbedded with its design than other dungeon based board games. The pace is a slow grinding configuration of unrewarding meaty decisions.

Gloomhaven is a generously sized package filled with surprises which included a lack of attention to detail in two fundamental areas; 1. Quality miniature sculpting 2. Forgetting to bring talented fantasy artists in to illustrate all its blank cards and other mundane components.

It’s lazy roleplaying, straight out of the box, hence the immediate popularity spawned by convenience. If I was feeling too lazy for a pen & paper campaign and wanted something easier to unbox with nicer art and a lovely selection of models to collect and paint then I’d be waiting for the relaunch of HeroQuest.

Gloomhaven is even more plain than its unimaginative title suggests, so it’s never going to be my fantasy campaign game of choice. I’d always prefer to be adventuring in somewhere drenched in tomes of arcane lore that matters. Somewhere like Mordheim.

Dungeon crawl game with a bit of a legacy game feel. The core mechanisms are relatively simple to play there are some rules that require referring back to the book at times. Card play feels a lot like Mage Knight but far less irritating as you can play any card for a basic move/attack action. At the end of the day though, it's just a hack-and-slash game where you move and attack over and over again until everything is dead or you've run out of cards; it just feels like an absolute slog. While I'm used to random combat from D&D/Pathfinder and having a personal combat modifier deck is a neat idea, the randomness of combat in this irritates me as the best laid plans can be blown away by 1 bad card draw. With RPGs you can react to a fluid situation whereas Gloomhaven requires you to plan your part ahead of time without knowing how things will be situated when it becomes your turn to act, and you can have a turn completely go to shit because another player or NPC acted before you and changed the state of the board. I hate the losing a card from your hand when you rest mechanic which serves as a rather heavy-handed game timer; run out of cards and you're forced to retire from the scenario. Did you lose your one remaining good card for this scenario? Too bad unless you want to give up the few HP you have left because everything has been attacking you. Hahaha, hope you like trying the same scenario setup the same way again! In something so combat focused, this seems rather harsh. Personal goal cards are randomly dealt out at the start of each scenario and you can get stuck with a card that is almost impossible to complete for your particular character which makes advancement tedious. Not being able to share gold is also incredibly irritating; the rules basically say you're a group of mercenaries who are in it just for themselves and refuse to share with one another - you're just together as a group as a matter of convenience. If a character satisfies their overall personal objective, they just leave the group and get replaced by another character. Killed all the baddies? Sure hope you looted all of that treasure because while the scenario had ZERO urgency, you can't take the few minutes necessary to round up that loot and you're forced to leave everything you didn't collect behind because reasons. There are some good idea in here but the majority of the game just irritates the hell out of me. Childres' first game, Forge War, was an infinitely more enjoyable experience in my books.

The fact that this overwrought monstrosity is #1 on BGG now seems like it should say a lot about where the hobby is now. Gloomhaven is pretty mediocre. It’s a total by-the-numbers design, with limited interest either narratively or tactically. It doesn’t have much of a sense of pacing or narrative direction. It doesn’t have an answer to the question of why it exists. As I say below, it’s total consumerism run amok; way too much physical product for the limited range of the game itself.

But it seems to have taken off; I assume on the strength of peoples’ affection for D&D back in the day (if they’re older) or MMORPGs (if they’re less old).

I think the reason I despair to some degree is that Gloomhaven is just such an uninteresting and unambituous piece of design and world building work. While certainly there is a lot of dreck in the boardgame space, there are also just so many people doing really interesting, thoughtful, and even meaningful games: Reiner Knizia’s Beowulf or Lord of the Rings, Spirit Island, Quartermaster General in all its incarnations, Catan in all its range and variety, Pandemic, Mystic Vale, Oath, the list goes on … that this relative mediocrity with little interesting to do or say is the #1 game on this site I think speaks to the problems in the hobby and, possibly, American society writ large.

So, I finally played this - 5 years late, well past when anyone cares about my opinion I’m sure. Still, I’ll put a few words down here.

Firstly, in this age of impending environmental catastrophe, the amount of stuff in this box is just absolutely criminal. It’s not a bad game, but it’s a game of repetitive stabbing with very limited range. How many times is clearing similar dungeons really fun? The designer has focussed on quantity over quality here, which might have been fine in the 80s but in the 2010s and 2020s we all know what is going to happen here if developed countries don’t moderate their consumption, or at the very least get smarter about it. It’s going to be quite bad. This is a pretty grotesque example of Western consumerism.

So for me personally, I just find the dungeon crawler genre of accumulating body count kind of dumb. Neither D&D nor its many copycat computer games are things I’ve ever been deeply involved in, and the raw amount of personally killing sentient beings for extremely unclear reasons does not sit particularly well. So a game in this category really has to bring it to win me over. Gloomhaven can probably work for people who have a pre-existing sympathy for the format. If you require it to do more than scratch a nostalgic itch, though? Probably not. It has the same failings as all the games in this genre: super-repitive, grind-y, minimally thematic, and of limited narrative interest. It’s a lot more interesting than the previous entry in this genre that I got significant exposure to, the Pathfinder Adventure Card Game. But that’s a low bar; that game was quite bad.

I had the wrong idea about Gloomhaven. I loved Pandemic Legacy. I think it is the single greatest board game I have ever played.

When Gloomhaven shot to the top of BGG, and beat Pandemic Legacy, I was ready to jump on it.

Legacy had drama, intrigue, suspense, and surprises! And, that is just from the gameplay! The story took you along a path that seemed to match the use and personalities of the characters we made. Every time we played felt like we were on an adventure curing pandemic diseases like “stupidity.”

I thought Gloomhaven, with its super high rating and rave reviews would give me the same feeling, for a longer time. It never did.

I didn’t realize that the story was largely of your own making. It was a tactics game rolled up in an adventure subtext. I didn’t know the story took a backseat to the fighting. It is a tactics game first, role playing second. Unlike D&D which has the Tick’s “drama power” where your story can change, and the nature of encounters is more fluid, Gloomhaven is set.

I respect the people that can squeeze joy out of this lemon. I did not enjoy the lack of meaningful payoff. Remember the end of Pandemic Legacy? It was amazing…I ‘member.

Regarding the digital version, soundtrack and narrations are good, but again, nothing that spectacular.

Why is this the best board game ever according to BGG? My best shot is that it appeals to people that would like to play tabletop RPG Dungeon Crawlers but don't have the time or impetus to actually do it. Is it better than those mentioned Old School Dungeon Crawlers? Absolutely not. Now, when it comes to the digital version, besides testing to know the game, I can't really understand why you would invest hundreds of hours into this game instead of playing any one of the better Dungeon Crawlers RPGs on PC out there (not to mention you won't have much of a deep story here by comparison to even the Dungeon Crawlers for PC of the 90s).

I know you will find a ton of positive reviews in this section, that's the nature of this beast, but here I am leaving you with a counterpoint and a message of support so you don't have to feel bad to pass on this title.

I played the game once and got a bad taste. A lot of work obviously went into developing the game, but I did not find it a fun multiplayer game. I found it to be a multiplayer puzzle and accounting game.

I like technical/accounting games, but it isn't what I look for in a dungeon crawl. In a dungeon crawl, I like playing a character and will keep track of odds to make sure I don't do something really, really, really stupid. The game mechanics forced me to play extremely out of character. I was a spell caster (Spellweaver) who was forced to leap (game mechanics "jump") through the entire crowd of final monsters in the first scenario to make the rest of the party attack, instead of taking it slow and picking opportunities.

You are forced to play cards or permanently loose cards every turn, sometimes both. There is a maximum limit to how many rounds a character can play before they are simply removed from the board. How you play and luck can reduce the theoretical maximum limit of rounds. The limit is not the same for every character and mine appeared to be the shortest. So I leaped in while half the party took a long rest (game mechanic), because I only had two rounds before I would have one card left and removed from the game. This is even though I was at full health.

I say I don't like it and I payed well enough to come out at the end with no damage, grabbing the main treasure, tied for second place for who picked up the most gold and I had the most XP (16 not counting the amount you get for completing scenario successfully). We did win on the first try with everyone still standing.

For a dungeon crawl, I would choose Mice and Mystic over Gloomhaven, because Gloomhaven can be more about card management/accounting than playing a character through a story.

That said, have fun and make sure everyone else does also.

Gloomhaven is D&D for eurogamers; it has slow incremental growth, character customization, and of course skull smashing. And Gloomhaven ports a lot of this quite well. The characters are unique and inviting, the world is evocative and new, and the card powers are fun from the start and only grow stronger with time. Most notable is the action selection mechanism which feeds into a palpable feeling of stamina drain as cards slowly leak out your deck and the scenario creeps to its conclusion. The problem is that Gloomhaven isn't fun. Despite all of its strengths, Gloomhaven is an overly protracted slog with unrelenting bookkeeping. I am a fan of heavy euros, but never has a game felt as laborious or as tedious as Gloomhaven. Even with my friend who'd setup the games in advance, and automate enemy damage/effect tracking, the game felt horribly burdensome. After six scenarios we called it quits and returned to the plethora of other games that bring us joy.

Let me start with this: Gloomhaven has an outstanding combat system. It's fun to play, rewards good tactics and strategy, and continuously throws interesting decisions at you. If it only was for its core, Gloomhaven would be a 9/10 game, only despite a few issues that can be lived with.

However, every single other aspect of the game is an absolute disaster. I'd rate these aspects a 3/10, so the average is 6/10.

- The progression system is flawed by nature. You get XP for playing certain cards and as a reward for completing certain quests. If you get enough XP, you level up. You get a nice new card and a perk for your attack modifier deck. That's terrific. The problem is how the game system responds to the players leveling up. It just increases the monsters' stats. This, combined with the fact that items and sticker upgrades don't count towards your character level (and they can MASSIVELY improve your character, even more than leveling up) makes the game easier as you progress. You will reach a certain point where the characters are too powerful. Fanatics always answer this saying that you can change the difficulty level to compensate that. That's recognising that the game isn't properly balanced.

- Retiring characters feels wrong to me. You've spent weeks building your character to a point you really enjoy using it. And someday, even by accident, you will complete your personal quest and be stripped of your beloved character. That just feels wrong. I know that the game encourages trying new classes, but it shouldn't impose it to you. Fanatics defend this system saying that you can perfectly create a new class of the same character you had. But you have to start again at a lower level, depending on the city's prosperity. This means that you've just lost all your items, most of your perks, and several levels. This, combined with the above point, makes progress undesirable. The fact that game dynamics punish progression is bad.

- But wait, retiring characters unlock really cool new classes. The unlockable classes are one of the worst aspects of the game. They are terribly unbalanced, with most of them overpowering the starting six, or being so niche that low player counts can unlock classes with total anti-synergies between each other. The whole progression system is just wrong. Team composition should be more in the hands of the players. It's nice to unlock new classes to try out different things, but forcing the players to change characters feels wrong. It's more problematic in low player counts.

- The story is pretty generic, but I don't play games for the story.

- Scenario design is wildly inconsistent. You have a couple great scenarios, highlighting the most simples: just kill every enemy on the board. That's the best kind of scenario. You have variety in the map layout, the monsters it has and, of course, your team composition. However, sadly most of the scenarios are poorly designed. Bosses are way too swingy, and so are the summoning enemies. They turn the game into a coin toss: if you get lucky, you may win easily. If you get unlucky, the game may be unwinnable. This phenomena also appears in many scenarios that can be way too random. And others can be cheesed with easy strats.

- Everything outside combat is pretty flawed as well. City and Road events are one of my most despised game mechanic: making uninformed choices. If you already know the game, you can memorise the events and make the best choice. Also, the fact that some decisions require certain classes to have a good effect, and the fact that this information is hidden, is just wrong. Events add nothing in terms of game mechanics, but if you like role playing you may like them, but this is not a game for role players, as the combat system is a brain burner. Battle goals are nice in theory, but everybody ends up revealing what they have to do. "Let me open that door" or "Let me kill that enemy" are common phrases within this game. Finally, legacy elements, in particular the closed envelopes, add nothing relevant. It's just hiding content for the sake of hiding it.

This game has the foundations of what the community claims it to be: the best board game ever. However, everything that surrounds the great combat system, which I had lots of fun with it, takes away the overall enjoyment of the game.

So I will preface this by saying that because Gloomhaven is so hyped, I came in with very high expectations which may be a bit unfair. And was only able to play a couple scenarios. But at the end of the day I was really underwhelmed.
Obviously the positive of Gloomhaven is it is a big box full of a lot of components that can entertain an individual or group pretty much indefinitely. There is almost no limit to the amount you can milk this game for, so I understand the appeal. Also, from an economic and mechanical perspective I can appreciate the game. Your figurines are very nice, and from a financial perspective, making the rest of the components cardboard makes sense. And the monster cards that can easily scale difficulty for your needs are a brilliant idea.
However, I had a lot of gripes. First, set up was an absolute chore. It took us twice as long to set up as it did to play the actual scenario. This could be mitigated if you could leave it permanently set up somewhere, but is absolutely prohibitive for a normal game night. Second, some of the mechanics were interesting and sort of fun. But the fact that you have to spend your valuable action cards whether you want to or not is thematically and mechanically obnoxious and silly. For example, I had to waste two entire turns (and therefore burn 4 of my dwindling action cards) just walking across a large room. I'm not quite sure why that mechanic exists, but it bothered me to no end. Likewise, there was a pit trap blocking a door. There is no way to disarm it in the game (besides jumping or pushing enemies into it, which my character couldn't do), so my character just had to walk over it and take damage. So for both of these fairly basic tasks that could be solved by some light exercise and critical thinking skills, my character was severely and illogically punished.
Finally, and in summary, I guess my take away is that Gloomhaven is basically a mash up of a DnD game and a Zombicide game, and it is far, far worse than either of those. If you want role playing dungeon crawling, Dnd is far richer and more fun. If you want a simple monster bashing game with your friends, Zombicide Black Plague is far easier to set up, more tense, and narratively interesting than Gloomhaven.
I guess in the end, the best use of Gloomhaven I can think of is if a person who doesn't have a game group can just set it up permanently on a big table at their house and just play alone when he/she has time. It just doesn't feel worth it to bring it out for even semi regular use for a group.

This is one of those games that every gamer should at least try. I enjoyed my plays, but it's just such a commitment. I can recognize Gloomhaven's genius and still say it's not for me. I would love to see the card system used in more games!

Update: I played again recently and to me it just feels so clunky. The card play is still cool, but overall it’s a classic example of “a lot for a little”.

Gloomhaven surprised me, not because it's a good game, but because it's actually pretty streamlined! Given the box is the size of my torso and punching the boards takes a full hour I was expecting some really complicated game that was a bear to play, but the play is super smooth and the phase order is so simple: play 2 cards, determine initiative, play turns in initiative order, rinse/repeat. The rulebook was admittedly intimidating, but things are relatively intuitive once you get going. I found it simpler to learn than both Descent and Mage Knight and it seems to do imitations of both very well

Don't get me wrong though; there are a lot of nuances in this game. If you haven't played games like Descent and Mage Knight then it might be a good idea to start there to properly appreciate how the core ideas of those games has been incorporated here. This at its heart is a cooperative game and as such it is missing some of the finer competitive elements of its predecessors. Then again Mage Knight and Descent hardly ever hit the table unless I'm playing solo, so we're not losing much

So the tactical dungeon crawling of Descent and the puzzly hand management of Mage Knight. What else is here? Robinson Crusoe's returning consequences is here too with the presence of travel events. There's an AI that is somehow even better than Gears of Wars's excellent AI system. I'm sure I'm missing a few others, but I'd say those together make up the core

The game is puzzly and thinky but not overbearing with process, and that makes it a slam dunk. Each class is complex and intricate with clear overarching strategies. Each kind of reminds me of a class in a MMORPG. Moreover, I've only played with two so far (both of which I'm thoroughly impressed with) and there are 15 more! What the heck?? I just got 4 hours of play from one session with these two and I haven't even scratched the surface with these characters. The amount of legitimately interesting content here is staggering

Gloomhaven just has to be a 10 for me. This is the perfect tactical dungeon crawl (unless you want something with a DM, then play Descent). There are a lot of effects but they are all relatively straightforward. There is a lot going on, but a good teacher could very easily abstract away the details from you. I love the classes and I love the puzzly nature of it all

I will criticize it for a few things though: first there's way too much stuff here. The game is starting to rival my Netrunner collection in terms of how I need to find ways to systematically manage it all efficiently. And I just opened the game. Moreover, sifting through cards during setup, digging through bags of tokens - it all really adds up. The game is not short by any means. My learning game took around 4 hours which included searching for clarifications on BGG. I don't see this ever taking less than two hours. Lastly, I should clarify: this game feels streamlined to me compared to other similar heavy games. There's still a lot of rules and a good amount going on - I just find it easier to remember than in other games which tend to have more branching conditions

Overall though, I'm extremely impressed with Gloomhaven. It far exceeded my expectations and I look forward to playing it again

EDIT: I've gotten to play about 10 games so far and wanted to update my thoughts. So far I'm still really enjoying the game although I think it's just shy of perfect for me. All of my plays have been solo playing two characters although I just introduced a third character on my most recent play.

The good: lots and lots of content, tactically very rich, streamlined phases, interesting characters, challenging, not a lot of rules referencing mid-play, progression is well-tuned and compelling, enemies require different strategies, clean and strong AI

The meh: bookkeeping is fiddly, attack modifier decks are cool but fiddly, long playtime, pacing seems a little slow considering how long fights take, a few of the scenario elements seem like they don't add enough value to justify their overhead (prosperity, reputation, events), you need to work if you don't want to legacy-ify your copy, rulebook is passable but not excellent, the randomness is tableflip-inducing at times

I tried out a few apps and am really happy with Esoteric Software's web app for managing combat. It's let me pick up a third character without much trouble and I don't think a fourth would even be too much

Overall I really love the game - my biggest complaints would be the bookkeeping and the pacing. It's a little frustrating to see two hours go by and realize you've only cleared two rooms but that's the cost of such a detailed and puzzly game. Still a winner, just knocked down a half point

I am a bit flummoxed by Gloomhaven. I really enjoyed my time with it, but a third of the scenarios feel underbaked, and it is a strange case of there simply being too much for a tabletop format.

The cardplay is great fun, and I'm glad other games have similar systems that work a bit better (Pavlov's House), the characters are very interesting and do play differently, and I think the shoddy-but-fun writing hits on the 1980s Fighting Fantasy novels some of us grew up around.

But it's too much. It is full of fluff like varying-similar enemy types with not enough to differentiate them; you don't need multiple decks of cards for them, add optional "flavour" cards into the existing Skeleton deck or something instead?

It's heavy, bulky, and very impressive. But with distance and time to think on the positive and negatives, there is some truth to the video game version being a much better experience. The board game replicating some notable dungeon crawler video games is telling, but the writing isn't good enough so it doesn't stand up to actual high quality tabletop RPGs, and the scenarios can be actually pointless and mundane copies of other mundane scenarios.

A great achievement, but with all important distance, I'd rather play a more refined game. I'm not spending 30 hours on a character's personal life goal card ever again, certainly. That sums up the rough edges of Gloomhaven.

As a side note, I enjoy the pretty grand Founders of Gloomhaven. If you get a chance, give that a go! I would love to see Isaac do more away from dungeon crawler campaigns due to Founders of Gloomhaven.

Really wanted to love this game, but over time the cracks started to appear. After about the 10th play session, I created a document for things I didn't like as a way to brainstorm house-rules to fix them. They might be crap but figured I would post it as it highlights the issues I have with the game.
Major Issues:
1) Upkeep and admin during play – Keeping track of events during play is a necessary, but should be reduced to its simplest form and should be combined to incorporate the major mechanics of your game. You can have many changes during gameplay as rounds/turns are completed. But it is necessary to create a system that changes the same things every time a round is complete. If you have a combat system that could include magic, special abilities, or experience points, then 1 mechanic should be included that does all of these things. For example: Magic the gathering is one of the most varied and complex games there are, but the foundations are the same for most games.
- Roll for who goes first and then turn order is determined clock wise. This is established at the beginning and continues until the end. You Upkeep your board (turning everything active again, draw a card, and usually playing a land. Follow the same steps everytime to complete your turn. The mechanics are the same across the board but a simple combination of letting the player play specific cards in a specific order at a specific time, greatly adds variety without changing the core order of how things go. Once you have the basics, you build on that.
2) Repeatability should emphasized in the rules as well as the content. Combat should be the same across the board on who goes first, enemy movement, and attack patterns. However, fighting the same creatures that do the same thing every time or adding more of the same enemy or elite versions does not add more fun. Do not have the same enemies for consecutive missions or quests. For example, if you only have 10 different enemy types, you can easily make them stronger as the game progresses. But do not make the players fight 4 consecutive scenarios with different variations of the same enemy. For example, after completing 4 scenarios in Gloomhaven, we fought skeletons (move 1-2 spaces, attack range or melee) Bandits (move 1-2 spaces, attack range or melee) Marauders (move 1-3 spaces, attack range or melee). This is the same enemy with a different name.
3) Make events thematically correct. Don’t include stupid missions like helping a kid find is cat, becoming exhausted from doing so and then removing experience points the player has gained from previous missions. That makes no sense. Have a negative consequence relate to the situation (while looking for the cat in the abandon warehouse, you stepped on nail and take damage, or have to go last in initiative, or have no movement on your turn.
4) Give all players the ability to revive or safe their teammates. For fucks sakes Gloomhaven’s system could have 1 party member get attacked by 2 enemies and go down and be out of the scenario completely. Then the player has to sit there and watch. At least give each player the ability to save their friends and bring them back once a scenario.
5) Give the players basics they can fall back on that actually matter. Don’t let them just move 2 and attack for 2 if they can’t use their abilities. Let them double their movement, or double their attack, or Heal themselves or their teammates for a small amount. Some times moving 2 and attacking for 2 does nothing when enemies are 4 spaces away and your party is being slaughtered.
6) Encourage tactics and cooperation. Do not state in the rules that they have to be vague on what they are going to do. This is confusing and discourages players from working together to maximize their efforts and leaves each player fending for themselves and only encourages the maximum play for the individual. When its obviously more satisfying to play weaker cards that could boost the effect of a member of your party.
7) Make rewards simple. If your system rewards gold for killing an enemy, then do not make them sacrifice their turn or action just to collect that loot. (In Gloomhaven, you can also be robbed on the road and loose everything you worked for). Incorporate picking up the loot in their actions. Do make them use an action to “Loot” or end their turn on that square to pick it up. Let them easily collect the reward by having to at least touch that square during their movement.
8) Don’t gatekeep powerful items. In Gloomhaven, you only have access to a pool of items that is based on party’s reputation. Fuck that, not only does that not make sense thematically (Why would a vendor care who buys an item if they have the coin) but it also railroads the players. Make the really powerful items really expensive so if the party wants to pool their gold and buy that one item to do something cool, let them. Make one time use items cheap to purchase but focus on permanent items they can keep and build over time. These items can complement the exact build they are looking for.
9) Use dice, not cards for variety. Instead of making 50 different decks for modifiers, create a system that uses dice to add bonuses for combat. Dice, like a standard D&D starter, can be customized for each character type and can even be used outside of playing your game. There are too many cards that need to be in order and numbered at the bottom for each character and enemy and is completely unnecessary. You can scale level progression by the type of dice used. Oh, your level 5 now, so your attack bonus is a d6 instead of a d4. Gloomhaven will want separate piles of cards for each modifier. Also, the board gamer type will always appreciate and see the value of more dice. Not paper cards that are ruined with one drink spill.
10) Make level progression meaningful. Gloomhaven, I received 1 more extra point for HP, got to pick 1 card that had to replace 1 card from my hand but still only had 10 cards to choose from. No new items in the shop.
11) Let players swap items or loot unconscious party member items during gameplay. How dumb is it that a player could have a potion of healing they didn’t get to take before going down or unable to give that to another party member that may need it to finish the scenario.
12) Cardboard is inferior to laminated paper maps. For fucks sakes Gloomhaven has cardboard cutouts to link together with different sides and digging for some symbol on the underside of another. Then provides punch out cardboard for traps or other things to add to those pieces that get moved around during gameplay anyway. I know this is for adjusting the level of difficulty based on the number of players but why not create a scalability difficulty not based on the terrain. For example, have the same traps in a given dungeon, just have them do less damage or reduce the effects they have. Its dumb to build a difficulty system based the number of environmental factors as it is to adjust their impact. You could laminate 25 paper maps, with different dungeons on the underside and have 50 unique locations that already have everything set up besides the enemy locations. You can even design them so that they connect on either end as the story progresses. This would protect the maps from mildew or liquid damage and make it easier to set up each scenario. You can also control the quality of the art, so door ways look like doors, instead of an off centered punchout of cardboard art that looks like a rock.
13) Status effects should go on the mini and combat board, not the life tracker of each enemy. Everyone is looking at the board, stop wasting peoples time by planning a whole turn around an enemy who might attack and kill your teammate to find out after doing damage that they couldn’t attack in the first place. Little circles that go around the base, for fucks sake.
14) If you are going to ask a consumer to pay $200 for a game with 9 plastic 3d minis and 100 cardboard cutouts for enemies, just increase the price and make all the minis be the same. Maybe offer 1 cheap option all cardboard cutouts and a more expensive version 3d printed but mashing the 2 together is stupid. 2d creatures can only be clearly identified at 2 angles and the artwork can only be appreciate 10% of the time. Reduce the cards, cardboard cutout maps, status effects, round markers, character sheets, number of enemy types, cheap Hp and exp counters and put that money into the 3d prints of minis that people can use again for a d&d campaign. Look at that, dice, 3d printed minis, and laminated maps that could be used even after the campaign has been completed.
15) Don’t make characters that resemble starter characters in dnd with 8 HP and can be taken out easily in one round. Spread out the damage or effects so characters have the chance to intervene with their decisions. Nothing more annoying than 1 player with full HP attacking on their turn, to have a teammate go invisible and become the only target, and then be the only target for multiple enemies that can kill them in 1 round. That should not be the norm.
16) Create an interesting core game inside the campaign that can be played in the future after the campaign has been finished. For fucks sakes, Azul is a great game with some tile pieces and core rules. Maybe a battle simulator or something.

[Digital version review] One word comes to my mind when I think about Gloomhaven: meh. Everything about this game feels just meh. Although the core mechanism sounds interesting on paper, it can get repetitive quite early due of combos.

Furthermore, some actions are very situational (destroying obstables, disarming traps) but very often they're discarded by the time you would actually need them and it's not really possible to plan this ahead because many things are hidden when you enter a map. While it is possible to repeat a map after defeat - where is the fun in repeating every single map before finishing it? Considering how crucial action management is in this game it probably would have been better to use open maps with very little to no hidden information.

Writing of action management, I'm also not a fan of the "automatic miss" - attack modifier (you pull one out of a bag on each attack and they can be positive, neutral or negative) because misses can be tremendously punishing on big hits, if not scenario deciding.

Your bag of modifiers is one of three things that you upgrade during level up. The leveling system in this game is meh, too, imhb. It takes a while to level up and then you get +1 hp, one new action card with which you can replace an old one, a "perk" that let's you change your bag of modifers a bit (but none let's you remove the miss!! *groan*). None of these are particulary interesting or make you feel stronger. There are also ways to buff you by spending gold (items, blessings) but none of them are intriguing or necessarily game deciding.

Storytelling: also meh. It's your generic "adventurers meet in a tavern and go fighting evil guys, looting stuff and repeat the process ad infinitum." The story has no real depth to it, it just sets up hundreds of skirmishes that feel pretty much the same.

Overall, the mechanics had potential but the implementation is mediocre.

Full disclosure: I've never played the physical version of Gloomhaven. This rating is a combination of playing through the entirety of the digital version and knowing how it translates to the tabletop.

Gloomhaven as a video game is a pretty solid 8/10. The interface could be better and it could better clarify some of the poor rules text it inherits from the board game, but it's polished and made with love for the original product. For the fraction of the price it costs it's a great time if you're looking for a dungeon crawl.

Where this goes sideways for the tabletop version of the game is the sheer volume of setup/teardown/enemy automation/rules enforcement that you lose, and knowing that a 2-3 character party still takes 40-60 minutes to play out average scenarios in the digital version. Tabletop Gloomhaven has to be the easiest game to repeatedly cheat at by accident simply because there's just too many things to keep straight for the duration of time you're going to be playing it. The puzzle/scenarios are not interesting enough to warrant 2-3 hours grinding away on each, and the rewards of unlocking new equipment or characters don't keep the experience as fresh as one might hope. Sure there's new complexity to discover, but I actually found starting new characters to be deeply unrewarding because of the power hit your party takes by losing so much equipment. Truthfully, the one advantage I can give the tabletop game over the digital version is that when the randomizer deck throws out complete garbage that would lead to extending a scenario several more rounds, you could choose to just ignore this overall bad feature (mechanically the randomness is good, but in practice the lows stand out far more than the highs) and save yourself a bunch of time cleaning up a scenario you know you've already won.

You could not pay me to play Gloomhaven the tabletop game. I understand how it can be appealing to a certain gamer or group, but this is not a game for your average person. If you have even a passing interest in Gloomhaven, buy the PC game instead.

Single Player Campaign on PC Review: There is a feature that is prominent in old-school JRPG's where the heroes slowly but inevitably stockpile a massive amount of consumable resources through a 30+ hour game while fighting their way through a bunch of easy inconsequential enemies and then unleash these collected resources all at once on the boss waiting at the end of the game. Whether for good or bad, Gloomhaven has managed to infuse this feature into every single game session by way of the burn mechanic. The only genuine strategic mistake to make in this game is to expend resources on the unnamed hordes of early enemies rather than whatever is waiting at the end of the map. This is not fun for me but judging from the rating people give this game, others disagree.

I have played this game several times at my friend's place. I very much enjoy RPG/Dungeon Crawler games. However, my problem with Gloomhaven is how it compares to other games in the same genre that I own, notably Descent and Mansions of Madness.

I found Gloomhaven to sort of "empty" in terms of what it attempts to be. The game has a beautiful world map and characters with deep skill sets. The game board itself though I find ugly. Everything is all a shade of reddish brown, and each mission map feels the same. Your party is adventuring in a Crypt? Reddish Brown tile. Your party is adventuring in the mountains? Reddish Brown tile. I compare this to Descent which has , in my opinion, beautiful tile work and game boards.

I also find that most of the monsters encountered feel stale. I played about 7 missions in the game (each of which took several hours) and most of what we fought were bandits and skeletons. Now that in of itself is not a problem. However all every monster appears capable off is march forward and draw an attack card. None of them appear to have unique abilities or skills that make them memorable. Further the monsters are represented by carboard cards rather than mini models. This may not be a concern for everyone, but I found it lower quality given the price.

I did find that each story mission takes hours, with very little payoff in the end. Most the of the rewards were pretty bland. Hours of play were rewarded with perks like "draw one less -1 attack card", and the items felt mostly the same.

In the end it maybe I would need to play even more to get to some better unique content, but given I have probably played this for 20 plus hours already I would say there are better options out there.

So rather than a stealthy dungeon crawl, you have a ‘kick the door down and kill everything as fast as you can’ dungeon crawl. Then you do the exact same thing again, and again, and again…..

My personal biggest board game disappointment, that fails for me both as a dungeon crawler, AND and a tactics game:
Heres why:

- You are in a constant pressure to rush forward, as your deck constantly decreases. Which disables any feeling of exploration, AND adds a lot of stress!
- When enemies are revealed, all of them get an instant action. Which will lead to a lot of instant-deaths.
Be prepared to replay missions, until you have learned what to expect, and can adapt.
- Combat is very random: You have to play your cards, before you even know the turn-order, and you then draw combat-modifiers for each attack on top. Which leads to very unpredictable tactics.

Gloomhaven is an incredibly ambitious game, and a bit of a beast. It's a legacy RPG dungeon crawl, but it distinguishes itself from other similar campaign or one-off skirmish games with the sheer quantity of content (it has 95 distinct scenarios and roughly 1,700 cards), card driven mechanics, sense of progression, and story elements.

I tend to dislike most combat dice resolution systems, and I much prefer the combat deck system in Gloomhaven. It allows more gradual changes to combat ability, and I like the probability distribution better. The hand management is also an interesting constraint, and serves to drive a lot of the tension in combat.

Gloomhaven is a commitment, but it's a good chunk of what I wanted out of RPGs like D&D and more than I expected out of a campaign dungeon crawl.

On the other hand, there are a few areas where I see room for improvement. While the game comes with an incredible amount of content, particularly for it's price point, the component quality is not the best. It's serviceable, particularly if you sleeve the cards, but many similar games have higher quality components. Probably a fourth or less of the actual content, but nicer components. The box really doesn't come with a good method of storing the components, so you'll need to figure out a storage solution.

In addition, I wish that there were fewer places I had to look to resolve a monster turn. You need to look at the monster action card and compare that against the attack modifier and the monster ability card every time they attack, and if that could have been streamlined down to 2 places to look I feel like the combat would flow more smoothly.

It's also a long game; a scenario can easily clock in at 2+ hours, and a campaign is ~60 scenarios. In some ways I wish that the combat was faster paced, and more emphasis was placed on the encounter cards and choices outside of combat. I really enjoy the road and city events, and I'd like to see that idea fleshed out more. Sometimes the combat goals don't line up with your character's long term goals or play style, and I would have liked it more if the battle goals were tied into the character's career goals more or at least given more thematic justification.

There are some other aspects of Gloomhaven that are poorly implemented. The class balance could use some work, many class cards are unnecessarily awkward to use, summons are awkward and often useless, it feels like you should be able to move more freely if you don't do any other actions, and the action economy for some of the long term effects and looting creates awkward situations and tempo problems for certain classes.

Still, Gloomhaven is a big step in the right direction, and there is a lot of fun to be had with it.

For the amount of stuff in this box, there's not a lot of variety. All the missions are either "kill X monsters", "go to place X", or "survive X turns". All the monsters act similarly and you'll have seen them all before playing half the missions. The classes are cool and unique, but you'll likely have to grind missions you've already completed to unlock them. Some nights just feel like a slog to unlock some reward, which makes me question why I'm playing.

The game is too fiddly. There's so many tokens, but you'll run out of some (or game won't have enough to set up a mission). Enemy management is cumbersome when they reach double-digit counts. Over the course of a night, you'll invariably forget to assign battle goals, or track the elements, or account of the elite monster's shield, or track your experience for a special card, or some other bit of minutia. It's incredibly disheartening to be the one leading the game and to have another player point out a single mistake after several minutes of monster upkeep.

The combat is tactical, but you're not given many options to create tactics from. Obstacles aren't prominent and don't block ranged attacks, so the only strategic positioning options revolve around doorways. You frequently have turns that just require you to get hit a lot and your only option is to try and split up your group to trick the AI into splitting the damage. You'll also need to chain together action combinations across multiple turns, but an unlucky enemy card draw can cancel everything. The game asks you to meticulously plan, but can easily upset those plans and leave you with no real options.

Gloomhaven doesn't deliver a sense of grandeur. The main plot tangents away very quickly and you're left with random threads you'll forget how you started. You're given random events, but most of them amount to "do an interesting thing" or "ignore it". Even if there is a choice, you'll typically follow your party's alignment, which removes the actual "choice" part. All the text does build an interesting world, but I'm left wishing I could instead play a real RPG in that world.

There are little things too: typos, rule ambiguities, a lack of token baggies, a nonsensical box inlay, poorly balanced scenarios, arbitrary item pricing, the too-small-for-damage-tokens monster card sleeves, and a lack of player quick reference sheets. There's some fun moments to be had and a ton of content. I get why this game exists and why some people would love it. I don't really understand why it's #1.

Would be a good game if playtime was halved. The main problem with the game is that it tries to be both a lite RPG, in a more accessible Board Game format and fails at both.

For example the playtime for the game I feel is too high for what I felt is an RPG on rails format, missions on average took us 3 hours playtime (not including setup) with occasional replays of failed missions required. Doing this once a week it took us over a year to complete the main story missions alone (there were still loads of non story missions left).

The investment of time would be fine if the RPG elements were more rewarding, but unfortunately the game restricts your character development and player choice immensely.

The game tells you when you have to stop playing as a character, the gold you collect becomes useless essentially once your character dies (you can upgrade cards with it but this is restricted greatly), you can only choose from a tiny list of levelling bonuses.

In addition to this the pace at which some characters, weapons and items unlock is glacial. You can easily pour 36 hours into the game and maybe only have a third of the items and weapons unlocked to purchase. And because these items don't carry over to the new character every time you are forced to pick a new character, you start on a low level with virtually no items. This means you can easily spend most of the next few missions grinding for items purely to be some help to your group.

In summary although in many ways an enjoyable game. I feel Gloomhaven was simply too repetitive and restrictive an experience for me as a player, to recommend anyone else investing the time required to play it fully.

After losing in the same dungeon (second one IIRC) we broke our "we must complete each dungeon 100% fairly" rule and fudged around a tiny bit. Did we win, sure, even on normal it was easy to beat the AI, did it feel good purely attacking the enemies, never looting the treasure and only situational getting the "gold" tokens while cheating a tiny bit not to exhaust? We even made it a point to play as hard core strategically as we could thinking out every move and turn to maximize every drop of out abilities and we still barely managed to squeeze by. (FYI we were playing the rouge and the mindthief). This all changed when we added a 3rd teammate (the brute) where the difficulty flipped to, too easy. We could position the brute to take the hits, move around the dungeon to key areas and land great hits while collecting the bonuses (other than treasure of course, because that is always impossible). Now the game is played either with a difficulty drop of 1 or 2 in 2 player and a difficulty increase of 2 or 3 in 3 or 4 player.
