While I was super excited when the we got the game and watched to rush into it and play as much as possible (thinking it would be a less heavy version of KD)...it has just died after about 20 missions and no one really volunteers it as an option to play during game night anymore.

Lots of really nice features in the game like variety, replayability, depth, good stories, unique characters, etc.

There is one big drawback though, lots of annoying procedures, some of which should have not survived proper play-testing.
All that shuffling and reshuffling is killing the game. You waste so much time doing that that your scenario takes from 5 to 15 minutes longer (depending on the size of the scenario).
Replacing the eight monster cards with a table you roll onto would have maybe removed the surprise of what is behind he next card, but it would have removed lots of useless procedures.

I have nothing against heavy games but as long as they use mechanics and not procedures. Because when to do procedures, you are not playing, as for mechanics, you do things because of an action you did. For example, Agricola is a heavy medium game that has mechanics and just two small procedures each turn (turning turn card and adding things to the board) which does not bog game play much. In Gloomhaven, you shuffle your deck, you shuffle the monster's deck, the other players shuffle their decks, you must draw a monster card for each monster type, you must draw and attack card for each monster miniature, you must draw a card for each attack card of your character, the other players do the same, etc.

This card system belongs to another age, the 1980s.

I am certain that we can figure out a much more efficient way to play Gloomhaven that would reduce the time scenarios take to finish by a good 20%. Not to mention diminishing the box's content and weight (thus reducing its cost so it will sell more).

Our group of game designers and our coaches hates procedures. There are too many small rules too.

Unless streamlined, like Arkham Horror this game would be best as a video game than a board game right now.

Without the heavy procedures and small rules, this game is a 9/10.

You like dungeon crawls? You like tactical combat with tough choices every turn? You like a massive world where your decisions actually shape the story? Here it is, Gloomhaven which is KIND OF A LOT OF BRAIN POWER THINKING XD! A 1–4 player cooperative campaign game where you and your party of adventurers dive into dangerous dungeons, forgotten ruins, and branching storylines that change every time you play.

How do you win? By working together to survive the scenario in front of you slaying monsters, grabbing loot, and making choices that ripple across an ever changing world. But don’t get too comfortable… every decision changes what comes next, and like a giant “Choose Your Own Adventure,” your story can twist in ways you never expect.

The core of the game is its brilliant card-based combat system. Each round, you’ll pick two cards from your hand, using the initiative number to see when you act. Each card has a top and bottom ability attack, move, heal, or something crazy powerful and you’ll play one top and one bottom every turn. Sounds simple, right? NOPE, until you realize cards are your lifeline. Use them too recklessly, and you’ll burn through your deck and exhaust yourself before the dungeon is done.As you play, your characters grow stronger, unlocking new abilities, gear, and even whole new adventurers to swap in. But the world of Gloomhaven changes too—scenarios unlock, cities evolve, and your party’s reputation can shape the fate of the land.

This is a dungeon crawl game with a sprawling ongoing campaign and certain legacy mechanisms where you alter the map, and your characters across multiple plays. The game is completely diceless, so it relies on a flip-luck card driven combat modifiers, which are a little more interesting as over time you can customize the contents of the various combat decks to a certain extent.

The writing is well enough for a game like this. Not terrible, but not very compelling. The components are rough, as rather than this being a game with tons of nice minis, everything outside of player characters are standees which can be hard to see or differentiate from each other. Health and monster stats are also tracked off on the side of the board, which means it can get confusing as to which monster does what and who has however much life left.

Mechanically players are fueled by ability cards, where you choose two cards from your array, then use the top half of one and the bottom half of the other. At times this can be an interesting puzzle, but over the course of the game you wind up losing cards from your array, and when the players lose a map, it's more often to players falling over due to not having enough cards left to finish than it is to actually getting trounced in an interesting tactical puzzle. I find this to be somewhat disappointing when it happens.

Downtime between turns is also quite long not only because of the awkward bookkeeping but also because as players chose their cards for the next round. They aren't allowed to talk about what they plan to do specifically, so turn order flies a little blindly with players stumbling over each other at times.

I only have 4 plays under my belt so far, but I think it's been sufficient to get an idea of the general slant of the campaign experience. The parts I enjoy are mainly legacy-level and the use of delayed consequences, the slow reveal of scenario chains, sidequests, simple Crossroads cards events, and world state changes. The legacy conceit works very well with this genre.

However, I'm still not quite sure where I stand with the core of the scenario play. It seems to take the concept of a D&D 4th edition session, deconstructs it down to micro-events spread across dual purpose cards, then re-assembles it into something where you spend every initiative round frowning at cards, deciding which to chain together, which will be ok to discard for the next X rounds, which will be good to burn for the rest of the scenario at certain points, table-talk about who moves where, who can infuse the battlefield with an element that someone else can use with their card, etc, etc... all for a single round in a skirmish with a handful of bandit fodder.

It sounds interesting on paper but it can be taxing, especially if taken as an experience of playing a board game emulating an RPG-in-a-box. Looking at it from that angle, I feel like the freedom and playfulness, and straight up velocity of the genre is pared down to cardplay that feels oddly restrictive, fussy, and slow despite the agency that it provides in the game (and those cards do allow you to do some really cool stuff). It's like you have to squeeze through this gauntlet of boardgamey analysis, just to pull something off that would have taken quick clearance from a DM and the roll of a d20.

But I think I have to resist looking at it from that angle because I suspect that the smaller narratives being churned through game mechanics is exactly what a board gamer coming at this genre from their own angle may expect. Case in point, there are tons of Mage Knight fans. I'm not one of those fans, for somewhat similar reasons as I'm conflicted about this game. This takes Mage Knight's crunchiness of systems propelling simple diegetic events and extends it, almost obscenely, across potentially years worth of play.

It's kind of a baffling game for me, at this point. It's something to be marveled at, but it's also a commitment that I'm not sure I'm going to find anywhere outside of solo play. My game group is most definitely not ready for this, and my son, who normally eats up this style of card play, is turned off by endlessly shuffled, swingy modifier cards (effectively a mutable d20, disguised to assuage die aversion) that can easily tank an hours-long scenario. So yeah, there it is on my table: a sea of solo campaign play, but also a brain burn. I'm not sure how often I want those two aspects joined together.

Edit: I don't need those aspects joined together, like ever. When I'm in the mood to play Brass Birmingham, I play that. When I want a satisfying dungeon crawl or adventure system, I play anything *other* than this. Donated to a curious friend, with zero regrets. This game simply isn't for me.

Popular BGG number 1 rank Euro dungeon crawl legacy game by Isaac Childres. Very puzzly hand management: choose two cards and use the upper part of one card and the lower part of the other card. One of these cards also determines your initative for a round.
Gloomhaven has two layers of gameplay: tactical combat and questing on a world map with trading for equipment and dealing with random (binary choice) events.

I like:
+ Great app on Steam that takes care of the annoying set-up, tear-down, rules, and bookkeeping
+ Massive amount of content (to unlock) and play time for hundreds of hours
+ Great tactical combat hand management system (card driven, a lot of decision making: discard the card for the rest of the combat, pick one of the different action on the card, modifier cards add uncertainty). Your remaining cards also act as an additional life meter for your hero (no more cards, hero gets exhauted)
+ There are also strategic aspects which cards to burn (unavailable for the rest of the encounter)
+ Monster combat AI is quick but sometimes stupid and unthematically. However, monster movement is complex and error-prone (not deal breaking)
+ A lot of different characters and monsters to unlock who play very differently (some may be better or more fun than others)
+ Unusual retire mechanic where your hero disappears and you choose a new, different character (variety). This also mitigates problems that normally occur when playing with (overpowered) maximally leveled heroes
+ Equipment and perks provide additional boosts
+ Difficulty adjusts well with different players and levels
+ Artwork

Neutrals:
# Mostly deterministic, however, some luck of the draw (resolving combat modifiers)
# Life goals are neat and fun in the beginning
# Mixed components, overall good production
# Player count: 3-4 players complement each other better than 2 players. 3-4 player will unlock more envelopes but takes longer to complete a mission. 2 player is more difficult
# Solo: play two heroes
# Simple multiple choice quests that may change the story of the game
# Drawn battle goals may be hard to achieve with certain characters
# Players' summons are controlled by AI who act quite stupid and inefficient
# Elements add another layer but also more bookkeeping
# Big game box (which is necessary for its content)
# Table hog
# Kill all monsters as usual win condition
# Story is okay at best. Focus is on the puzzly combat
# Combat system is good but can also be frustrating when you have to waste actions
# Restricted communication: initiative values.

- Repetitive, slow grinding is a big aspect of the game's progression

- Long setup / teardown (longer than an actual game)
- Big rules book and the rulebook has several ambiguities. Hard to learn
- A custom storage solution improves usability a lot
- Random events between encounters where you choose one of two options which provide negative effects
- There are some semi-coop elements (personal combat objectives, life objectives, looting, no equipment sharing). Thematically, all players are selfish rogues. This feels a bit odd at times, because overall the game appears more like a fully cooperative dungeon crawler.
- As you lose cards over the course of the battle, your options diminish over time.

Similar games:
* Sword & Sorcery
* Dungeon Alliance (very deterministic dungeon crawler and deck building, scenario-based, story expansions available)
* Middara (fully cooperative JRPG inspired miniatures adventure, dungeon crawl, campaign game, simple dice-based combat, weak story)
* Too Many Bones (dice-based skirmish game, more randomness, less deterministic, no big campaign, less time consuming)

Congratulations! You have found the most overrated tabletop game of all time. I have a theory as to why it has such a high rating: given its huge price point and time requirement, I assume that most of the people rating are people who bought it after researching it thoroughly in order to ensure that they would enjoy it. This certainly is not an impulse buy game.

Positives:
* The action system is fairly clean; I like that all actions are card-driven, each card has default modes, and your deck acts as a timer of sorts.
* Lots of variety between classes.

Neutral
* Retiring heroes is thematically a bit strange, but I can see how it does guarantee you'll get to experience a variety of heroes.

Negatives:
* Tedium to the max. Repetitive quests. Yet for those who want a crunchy, heavy dungeon crawler that takes literally months to complete... this is it. In that sense, it is quite an impressive accomplishment.

If you want the gameplay stripped of all of the tedium, check out the digital version. I still find it too tedious even in this medium. So many better digital dungeon crawlers out there (Darkest Dungeon being the best, hands down), but I can see this being fun if you have friends you want to play with.

But here's the problem: The mechanics don't suit the length of the campaign.

I love long, thinky, heavy, puzzly games like Mage Knight, the Mistfall series and even Unicornus Knights.
But you sit down for a few hours and play them ONCE! Then you're free to pack them up or reset, change characters/scenarios and play again.

But I LOVE CAMPAIGNS!! It's just that I think I prefer campaigns for games that are lighter. Games like WarhammerQuest ACG, Descent 2nd Ed, Pathfinder ACG, Sword & Sorcery etc where combat can be streamlined with a quick dice-chuck and some clever card play to mitigate the risk of poor luck

I think I'd prefer this game to either be a dice chucker and keep the campaign
OR

I'm in the camp of folks that think this shouldn't have ever been a board game. This system only works well as a video game, and in the world of video games, it has stiff competition.

Having said that, learning the adventurers and working out team compositions is quite fun. The Rest system also makes for tight games, which I appreciate.

Things I love: (The Card System!)
- A fresh take on multi-use cards: select two, then use the top action of one and the bottom action of the other. Also, a card sets your starting order, which adds to the complexity and decision-ing.
- Rest system: Take a full turn of inaction to take a better version of a card refresh action? Or take the instantaneous one that adds penalty of luck of the draw?
- This decision is also important for tempo/longevity, as taking Short Rests leads to more quickly running out of cards and becoming Exhausted.
- (Not part of the cards) Traps combined with push/pull effects make for some clever turns and fun postioning

Things I dislike: (Everything else)
- There are just too many things to maintain and manage in a scenario. It isn't complicated, but does feel like a chore and takes me away from the fun of playing the cards.
- Combat resolution via the combat cards is clever, since they may be upgraded, but slows the game down (and again feels like a chore).
- The dungeon crawling aspect just feels lacking somehow. Maybe it is the slow chore (3rd mention) of collecting money and loot, or maybe it is that your character isn't able to upgrade (level ups or gear) mid-scenario, so working through the scenario just feels like a ...chore. I'd rather Diablo's approach of rewards *during* the combat, or Final Fantasy's shorter combats with rewards given inbetween.

It is a game I hope other games will draw insiration from, but not one I recommend.

Gloomhaven – A Heavyweight Classic That Shows Its Age
Rating: 7/10

There’s no denying that Gloomhaven is a landmark title in modern board gaming—ambitious, expansive, and offering hundreds of hours of content. Its tactical combat system and legacy campaign structure were groundbreaking at launch, and it’s easy to see how it captured the hearts of many.

That said, playing Gloomhaven in 2025 feels like wrestling with an outdated system. Setup and teardown are a chore, made worse by the complete absence of an insert or organizational logic. For a game that costs over €170, the user experience is surprisingly poor unless you're willing to invest in a third-party storage solution.

Component-wise, the disparity between expectations and reality is stark. A few unpainted miniatures, a sea of cardboard standees—even bosses feel underwhelming on the table. And despite the deep mechanics, the rules often feel more convoluted than clever. Even after multiple sessions, we kept stumbling over interpretations and edge cases.

When compared to something like Arydia, which offers painted minis, streamlined gameplay, and a beautifully engineered box—all at a similar price point—Gloomhaven starts to feel clunky and dated. Arydia simply delivers a smoother, more elegant experience straight out of the box.

In the end, Gloomhaven remains a notable and sometimes thrilling ride, but one that requires a lot of patience, housekeeping, and tolerance for rough edges. For some, it’s a masterpiece. For others, like me, it’s a good game trapped in a frustrating package.

Ever played DnD and felt like you needed something more visual, and a get a good prebuilt campaign in a pick your own adventure?
Gloomhaven might be the game for you.

Gloomhaven does work very well, and you get a lot of game for it's price point, I cannot understate the value portion of this game.
You have quite a few characters to chose from who all play differently, and choices do matter.

So why a 7?

The biggest drawback for me is the combat system, which is the main reason I docked some points.
Sooner or later unlike DnD you will end up fighting in a dungeon of sorts, and while those encounters are well built, I hate the "impending doom" mechanic.
What I mean is, you get a set of cards (bit of a deck builder) with abilities you can use, some are one time use and they get "Lost" others are discarded upon use.
You run out of cards? Rest, short rest you put a random discarded card in the lost pile, long rest you chose.
So basically every cycle you end up with less options until you "fatigue" and at that point it's game over.

Some people may love this mechanic, I personally do not.
A lot of pick your own adventure game are either story or combat focused, and with how gloomhaven is set up you'll do a lot of combat, which I'm all for but I don't feel like it works as well as I'd like.

Of course this is subjective, if this mechanic doesn't matter at all to you, or you like such a mechanic, this game is an easy 9-10 in it's category.

I have played 100 hours+ of the digital game and here are my thoughts (warning that they are mostly negative as the positives of the game are pretty obvious and the game is in the top 5 on BGG so is quite safe).

The game is broken. The game at its best is when you use a completely overpowered and unfair ability to clear a room of enemies or stun multiple enemies to make their turns useless. However this is not good game design.

Furthermore, the brokenness becomes unfun. The personal quest design is horrible. I have had players not be able to retire because we don’t want to replay scenarios to kill specific enemies needed for the quest. We haven’t even be able to retire one character who needs a specific scenario appear whereas another player has retired twice in 20 scenarios.

The scenarios range from trivial to nearly impossible with 4 players without using specific stun heavy/insta kill builds. It is incredibly tedious to replay a scenario you have sunk 2 hours into. The second scenario in the game seems to be one of the hardest for no apparent reason, how did that get past playtesting? There are definitely fun scenarios though.

The story is not interesting. There are no chat after motivations or nuanced plot points. You lose track of what’s happening very quickly with the story.

Some cards are utterly useless and some are must-picks, forcing you into certain play patterns across scenarios.

We have been using the house rule within digital to remove the x2s and misses. A lot of the time when you get a x2 it is wasted. However each time you draw a miss and you waste a whole planned out turn involving other characters it feels so incredibly bad.

I'd rate the physical version lower than the digital as I cannot imagine how tiresome it would be to do the monster turns, especially with 4 players where sometimes there are 10+ enemies acting each round. Well I can actually because I’ve played Jaws of the Lion with 2 players and that was enough.

Still a 7 because the card play and systems are great and fun with friends but the game is just too big in every way, causing it to be quantity over quality.

Tl;dr It's 22 lbs of amazing. This is like having an epic DnD campaign where no one has to be the DM.

Mostly dungeon crawls, and mostly about killing all the enemies, but as you explore, you unlock new locations. Players can also travel back to the city to re-equip and get random encounters on the road. All players form a party that can gain and lose reputation, increase the prosperity of the town, unlock global achievements, etc. Individual characters have personal goals that once they achieve, will retire and unlock new character classes.

Characters who complete missions will gain gold and experience, and can level up, gaining access to new skills and abilities. Characters can also improve their odds in battle by completing mini-goals during scenarios. They also can buy equipment, loot dead monsters, or open treasure chests to reveal more stuff.

Combat is handled by cards, and selecting which hand of cards you take into battle can be it's own puzzle, because your hand size is limited. Each round, you use up two cards, but if you run out of cards in your hand, you can shuffle discards, permanently losing access to one of them. If they all run out, you're exhausted and out of the scenario. There are other ways you lose cards from your discard pile as well If everyone becomes exhausted, you lose.

Randomness is also a factor, because each character has a combat deck that could improve or hinder their attacks, with one critical hit and one critical miss card. Players can modify this deck through achievements that grant perks. Players can select which perk to gain, and when a character retires, they can pass some of those perks on to the next character that player will use.

Monsters are controlled by some pretty basic A.I. rules, but each type of monster has its own deck of cards telling the players what they will do that round, as well as a monster attack modifier deck. Difficulty of monsters can be scaled from level 0-7, and each monster type has stats for basic and elite units (with special abilities). There is a fair bit of bookkeeping that has to be done during the round, and lots of little cardboard bits to help keep tack of temporary modifiers.

What's great about the game is the narrative arc that takes place during the scenario. Each player starts out with a whole lot of potential, and facing some known enemies, but no one knows what lurks behind closed doors. As they go through combat, their ability deck acts like a countdown timer until they will be exhausted, so there is a rush to blitz through all the enemies, but you have to have a plan.

In our first mission, there were three rooms, and after clearing the first room, two of us were almost exhausted, and I didn't think we would make it. And when we opened the third door to a room full of monsters, I was certain we were going to fail. But we managed to eke out a victory, and it was very satisfying to do so. The icing on the cake was the flavor text in the scenario book, which has 95 different story-driven missions. Add to that a map that unlocks locations as you play by placing stickers, and you have a very cool game.

Gloomhaven was the first co-op board game I ever played. I bought it in 2020 but only started playing three years later. I decided to buy it for two reasons: first, because I love fantasy role-playing games; and second, because of its high ranking on this very site.

My friends and I only finished our campaign this year, after playing for two years. The fact that we stuck with Gloomhaven for so long speaks for itself — we truly enjoyed the experience. More than that, the game helped strengthen our friendships, and I think Isaac Childres should be proud that his work has brought so many people together.

I know countless reviews have already been written about Gloomhaven. My apologies if I repeat what others have said or if my impressions add little, but I’ve arranged my thoughts in a simple list:

PROS:
-You’ll spend countless enjoyable hours with your friends — even outside of gameplay, while preparing the next session.
-Difficulty can be scaled easily.
-Huge variety of classes.
-More than 90 scenarios.
-Node-based campaign structure.
-The world reacts to your choices through a reputation system.
-Failing a scenario isn’t as punishing or frustrating as in Journeys in Middle-earth.
-Some scenarios are genuinely challenging and rewarding.

CONS:
-109 pages of rulebook and FAQ (!)…
-…largely because of confusing writing and a terrible layout…
-…where important information is poorly organized or even hidden (flowcharts, bullet points, or mind maps would have helped).
-No organizer included.
-Some components are of mediocre quality.
-Additional expenses are almost necessary: sleeves, organizer, and accessories.
-Increasing prosperity and reputation feels too slow.
-Players must track too much information…
-…and yet there’s no official app to help manage it.
-The sheer number of scenarios can discourage completionists.
-Some scenarios feel repetitive.
-The first few scenarios can be overly difficult.
-While many boss fights are fun, the final one is poorly designed and disappointingly easy.
-A few classes are noticeably overpowered.

RPG, hold the RP

I don't see how this is more strategic than any of the other high profile campaign games, for me, Imperial Assault stands head and shoulders above this one. I want to strategize about positioning and more creative missions, here, I mostly are shoehorned into attack patterns. It feels very limiting to have a puzzle on top of a dungeon crawler experience, especially the movement options are annoying.

That beeing said, I played this online on Steam only, so it might not be a fair assesment, and I played for 80 hours until I realized that I always thought I could be playing XCOM instead. Still, it was 80 hours of quite some fun, I think after 70 I felt the repetitiveness.

I think I prefer randomness of the dice in a dungeon crawler to randomness of the deck. Yeah, your bad card won't come back until you are through your modifier deck, but a 6-sided dice is just much more transparent in what can happen.

But the worst is really the samey nature of the game. It's interesting for 2-3 missions, but once you understand a character you are playing the same game for multiple missions. There are just certain patterns you repeat. Yes, there are some missions that are not "kill all monsters", but the KI isn't really aware if you have other goals, so monsters won't go out of their way or do long term plans to hinder you achieving the win condition (f.e. reaching a certain spot on the map), and it will take a lot of missions to get a new character.

Gloomhaven is a truly great and unique experience packaged in one enormous box. If you want a huge, well thought out, fleshed out dungeon crawl RPG in a board game format, this is the game for you. There are a couple of caveats, however...

The game is presented like a lot of RPGs, where you create a party of characters based on a set of pre-defined classes. Your party exists in the town of Gloomhaven and you complete various quests and tasks within the town itself as well as the surrounding area.

These quests are physically built from a very large collection of double sided tiles that provide a nice functional and aesthetic backdrop that defines each encounter. Typically speaking, your earlier and more simple encounters are smaller and as you progress through the game, the maps increase in size and complexity. Alongside the tiles themselves, you have a large stash of various environmental objects which serve as additional flavor to the environment but also serve as functional additions either in the form of impassable tiles or ones that break LOS, etc.

Quests are played in rounds, with each player character and each monster performing a set of actions based on initiative. Each player selects two cards, all of which have a top and bottom action, and chooses the bottom action of one card and the top of the other. All action cards have an initiative, and the player may choose which of their two cards will be their initiative for that turn. Monsters, likewise, have an initiative assigned to their action for any given round, and all participating parties from both sides take their turns in order. Once a player or monster resolves their actions for that turn, it goes to the next in order, and so on until the round is ended. Once used, a player's action cards are either discarded or lost for the remainder of the quest, depending on the card type. This serves as a sort of soft "enrage timer" for any given quest, so parties can't simply rest and heal between every encounter. There's always a sense of urgency in Gloomhaven. Any time a damaging action is resolved, the entity performing that action (Monster or player) will draw from a deck of random modifier cards that can change the impact of that damage by adding or subtracting damage, adding elements or other effects, doubling the damage, or even outright nullifying it.

As to the quests themselves - Including set up and tear down time, you can expect anywhere from 1-2 hours with some that fall outside of those bounds. There are 95 scenarios in the campaign and while you can't experience all of those in a single playthrough (Certain junctions force you to choose a path in a quest so you can't experience all of them while adhering to the rules), you can easily expect 150-200 hours of playtime out of this box in a single playthrough, not including messing with your characters, buying items, dealing with city and road events, etc. The quests are delightfully varied, and some of them impressively complex in design. The game has a natural difficulty modifier mechanic to make sure that players don't outpace the difficulty of the game, but it is left somewhat up to the player how challenging of an experience they want. You are rewarded for taking on higher difficulties, but enemy strength ramps up quickly. The game also modifies enemy spawns and strengths based on player count, so more is not necessarily easier.

In between missions you will have random encounters with the other denizens of Gloomhaven as well as encounters on the road to your quests. These serve to provide not only lore and flavor text, but meaningful ways for your party to gain a reputation - for good or ill - which has in-game impacts on various things. As usual, these things come with tradeoffs. Rob a defenseless merchant for quick gains, or be the good guy and slowly develop a good reputation that will pay dividends over time? The choice is yours.

Character development is one of the game's most robust features. Your party can contain anywhere from 1-4 characters, each required to be a different class, with one player controlling one character (My friend and I actually ignored this rule in order to experience more classes at once, and went through the game with 2 people controlling a total of four characters at once), and the rules are very intentional about keeping mid-mission communication vague and at a minimum, i.e. you don't reveal your actions for a round until everyone has already chosen theirs, and you can only speak in generalities as to your intentions.

As you gain experience through certain actions and complete missions and quests, you will find your character leveling up and gaining perks. Character progression includes your standard increase in health, but is also represented in two major ways: gaining perks and getting new action cards. Perks are mostly related to a character's action deck, either adding positive cards, removing bad ones, or adding effects like piercing shields or adding elements to attacks. There are other perks such as ignoring negative effects from scenarios and items as well. This is a sort of slow burn progression which serves to lessen the randomness of the modifier deck and make a character more predictably powerful over time. New cards are also ramped in their impact based on the level requirements but can also provide a more dramatic shift as certain key cards are drawn. This comes at a tradeoff, as the number of action cards for any given class does not change as they progress, so as new cards are acquired, old ones must be left out of the active deck.

In addition to character progression through perks and cards, you also have at your disposal the usual acquisition of helpful items and gear as well as the ability to modify your action cards after a certain point in the story line. This is an expensive but powerful means to permanently add a large number of different effects to your card such as extra damage, extra targets, extra area of effect, shield piercing, etc.

As you go along throughout the game and satisfy certain requirements you will also unlock the remaining classes in the game eventually adding 11 locked classes to the base 6. I cannot stress how different each of these are and while they're not all equal in their effectiveness, they are all certainly very interesting to play and very unique from one another.

As to those caveats I mentioned earlier...

Some of these things can be circumvented by a couple of house rules, and some with the purchase of the removable sticker pack. First off, the rulebook almost reads like you're really only allowed one playthrough of the game. It dictates that a lot of effects are permanent, not just for your party, but for your box. I don't like that. It's my game, I'll replay it if I want to. And apparently the good people at Cephalofair Games felt the same, and produced a very cheap set of reusable stickers to solve just that issue. I would highly recommend this for anyone playing Gloomhaven.

The second thing people might not care for is the stringent rules around character creation and retirement. When any character is created they draw two retirement goals and choose one of them. These vary wildly from "Kill X number of this type of monster" to "Complete this specific quest line". These all come with some form of reward, usually unlocking a new class, and generally speaking, take a long time to complete barring some freak occurrence. Here's the catch however, once you have met the requirements for a character's retirement, they retire and you have no choice in the matter. And for the most part you do not get to keep any of what they've acquired. The major exception to this is that the card augments you acquired are permanent, even for future iterations of that class, but since there are so many classes, the odds of you realizing the benefit of that are low. You can, of course, just recreate the same character again, but that's highly unadvisable given the number of classes the game has to offer.

On a more practical note, this game suffers from its own design quality in a few ways. First of all, there are a huge number of mechanics to keep track of. I'm not saying this is the most complex game I've ever played and for the most part the rulebook is a great resource (Though I have found myself googling for clarity on a fairly regular basis), but for the average board game player, this would be a daunting amount of rules to follow. It's simply too easy to accidentally forget to keep up with things and only remember later.

Secondly, even though the only miniatures in the box are the player classes and the monsters are all represented by cardboard icons, there is an intense amount of tokens in this box, with absolutely no thought given to how players are supposed to store things. This all but necessitates people to spend extra money on either a homebrew storage solution, or an expensive after market solution like broken token, etc. And I might add that regardless of which path you take to resolve this, none of them are ever going to allow you to fit everything back into the original box and have it close. While that is minor compared to a game with bad rules or bad gameplay design, that's pretty disappointing. Furthermore, there just isn't a good solution for how to store the map tiles, which I'm sure is why in the Jaws of the Lion side expansion, they changed their strategy to having the scenario book be the map. I personally like the map tiles but they are an absolute nightmare to manage from a storage perspective.

All of that being said, Gloomhaven is a truly amazing experience for any psuedo-hardcore board game enthusiast. It's a very well thought out design that produces an incredible number of unique play sessions with a great depth of player choice and freedom. The storage and rulebook challenges should be taken note of, but if you can get over those hurdles, you're in for one of the best board gaming experiences available.

I am completely in love with this game. It has all of the dungeon crawly goodness I craved, without the annoying randomness of DnD or Descent (yay no dice!). It satisfies the RPG lover in me with a huge persistent campaign with an ever changing world. It calls to the heavy eurogamer in me with tense decision making points with the tense decision making of the card system and custom attack modifier decks.

The game manages to be challenging even on the first mission, but not impossible at 2p. A sign of great difficulty scaling.

The only real downside is the setup (mitigated by different storage solutions).

+ Immersive persistent campaign that definitely scratches the RPG itch
+ Diceless combat system
+ Lots of customization for characters, from available action cards to custom a attack modifiers and equipment
+ Lots of classes to explore
+ Gameplay is rich and deep, often allowing requiring you to really plan and outsmart the AI
+ AI is easy to use and fairly intuitive

- Storage and cleanup/setup are a BEAST
- HP / XP tracking for monsters and players is fiddly
- There are a lot of small, easily overlooked or misunderstood rules that make the FAQ required reading

You open a door, and the dim torchlight reveals six more enemies awaiting you in the shadows. You glance at the five cards in your hand, already feeling the weight of exhaustion creeping in. You’ll need to be careful and resourceful, measuring every move if you hope to survive this ordeal. Discussions with your companions spill into tense whispers—each of you focused not only on the mission but also on your own private battles and elusive personal goals. Gloomhaven isn’t just a dungeon crawler; it’s a marathon. It demands a careful balance of rest and risk, strategy and hope.

After Jaws of the Lion, Gloomhaven feels like a natural expansion of that universe. How could you not like it? Mechanically, it’s ingenious and incredibly engaging. This time, the light legacy elements add variability and a level of customization that keeps each player’s experience unique.

Of course, as with any lifestyle game, some fatigue sets in after a while. The story itself leans on familiar fantasy tropes—after playing narrative-rich games like Tainted Grail or Aeon Trespass: Odyssey, Gloomhaven’s storyline can feel less compelling. Still, it’s a standout experience and remains a masterwork in the genre.

Why it is a 9:

Asymmetry: Everyone plays their own character with their own capabilities.

Progress: Characters get more options and feel more powerful over time.

Decisions: Most decisions are pretty important. The ones which aren't are usually quick to make so you can get back to the meaty decisions.

Variety: Enemies, level setups, character builds, mission goals (to a lesser degree), lots of variety promise to keep things fresh for a while.

Why it is not a 10:

Logistics: This game is somewhat of a logistical nightmare. Keeping track of the enemies AI, shuffling all the enemy decks when appropriate, knowing how the AI should act in an ambiguous situation, remembering all your own abilities and effects, going in turn order. Lots of things demand the attention of the players and it is easy to miss things. That's to say nothing of table space requirement and storage requirements.

Probably the best board game I've played. Hadn't played a fully co-op game before this, so was pleasantly surprised at the dynamics. Works best at 3p, seems easy at 2p, and takes a lot longer at 4p.

Pros -

1) Keeps you invested for way longer than other board games - I'm expecting a good two years before I tire of this game
2)The concept of unlockables is brilliant and keeps the enthusiasm levels high.
3) Every scenario is different (we are just 10 scenarios in), and every monster type adds a new dimension to the game
4) No dice rolls. The random luck elements are restricted to certain card events and attack modifiers
5) Players get to customize their characters and develop them the way they want to. Further, each character is unique, so meshing different playstyles is an integral aspect to the game

Cons -

1) Takes too long to set up and pack up
2) Storage. Need a good organiser or a 3D printer if you want to store all the pieces carefully
3) Tracking damages and monster HP's can be tedious, but we've solved that problem using apps on the side to reduce downtime
4) Need a dedicated crew

All in all, I think that the pros totally make up for the cons and this is a game worth its price and weight.

I’m absolutely in love with Gloomhaven. I’ve completed the entire campaign twice, which easily adds up to over 200 hours of gameplay, and honestly, I could keep going. It’s hands-down the best game I’ve ever played. Everything about it – from the mechanics to the world-building – just clicks.

The core hand management system is pure genius. You start each scenario with a fixed hand of 8–12 cards (depending on your character), and each turn, you pick two cards to play. These go into your discard pile, and when you rest to recover them, you lose one to the “lost” pile until the end of the scenario. To spice things up, some powerful card abilities go straight to the lost pile, so every turn is a tough decision. To make things even more interesting, you can sacrifice a card to avoid damage, which makes your cards the ultimate resource – they’re your stamina, your abilities, and your lifeline all at once. It’s such a clever system, and it keeps every moment of the game engaging.

The variety of characters is mind-blowing, and they all feel unique, even though not perfectly balanced. Character progression is probably my favourite part of the game. Levelling up, gaining experience, unlocking new cards, and completing perks to improve your modifier deck is incredibly satisfying. I was sceptical about the character retirement system at first – the idea of giving up a character you’ve built felt strange – but it turned out to be one of the most exciting parts of the game. Retiring a character and unlocking a new one (with fresh abilities and challenges) is a blast, even on a second campaign.

The game is definitely challenging, but even when we failed scenarios, it never felt punishing. You still gain experience, so even a loss contributes to your character’s progression. The combat mechanics – from the enemy AI and ability decks to the initiative system – are incredibly well-designed. Every round feels tactical and rewarding, and the game always keeps you on your toes.

I know some people think Gloomhaven is too complex, but I found it more approachable than I expected. Sure, it has a lot of depth, but once you get the hang of selecting and playing your cards, it’s pretty straightforward. Some ability interactions can be a bit tricky to figure out, but the Gloomhaven community is amazing. If you ever get stuck, there’s plenty of help online, especially on BoardGameGeek.

The production value is off the charts. The components are fantastic, and the artwork (shout-out to Alexander Elichev) really brings the world to life. The setting is unique too – it’s fantasy, but not the generic kind. It’s immersive without being overly grim, which strikes a perfect balance. I also love how the campaign branches, making it impossible to play every scenario in a single run. The dungeon tiles are another highlight for me – they’re much more immersive than a flip book.

I’ve seen complaints about the setup and tear-down time, which can be a hurdle for some players. For me, this was never an issue because I invested in a third-party organiser from day one. It keeps everything secure and saves so much time during setup and gameplay. Honestly, it’s such a game-changer that I can’t imagine playing without it. I guess requiring an organiser could be seen as a downside, but for me, it’s just part of the experience.

One feature I absolutely adore is the random dungeon generation mode. It’s like a Diablo-style rift run, and it’s everything I’ve ever wanted in a tabletop game. It’s perfect for when you want a quick, one-off challenge.

I know a lot of people suggest starting with Jaws of the Lion as an intro to Gloomhaven, but I actually disagree. If I’d started with JOTL, I might not have been interested in the full game. JOTL is fine, but it’s much more limited – no retirement system, fewer unlocks, fewer tiles, and much simpler gameplay. If you’re new, I’d recommend jumping straight into the full Gloomhaven (or waiting for the second edition in 2025). After that, try Frosthaven, and treat JOTL as a fun mini-game later on.

For me, Gloomhaven is a perfect 10 out of 10. It’s an absolute masterpiece and a must-have for anyone who enjoys tactical combat puzzles, cooperative play, or RPG-style character progression. If you haven’t played it yet, trust me – you’re in for something special.

Things that help game running smoother:
- The FAQs for first time play.
- Reduced setup time using organization trays and reducing what is needed from the box.

Well this ended up being interesting and unexpected for several reasons, and genuinely great. TLDR: (1) I loved it, after a decidedly mixed experience with JOTL. (2) I think it’s a rare digital-is-better situation. And (3) Less than 4P is the way to go.

(1) JOTL was my introduction to the system and I have a lot of mixed feelings about it. One can see my full comments there but I played a full campaign with a group of 4. I loved playing with friends but it suffered from a tedious story, mediocre sloggy level design, overlong game sessions, and we were all glad to be done with it. Still, the system and card play was a real winner and I could grok the seed of what it *could* be. Swapping Full Gloomhaven for the underbaked JOTL, playing digitally on Steam, and with 2 or 3 mercenaries, did the trick. I've been straight up obsessed with this game. I've now played two full campaigns and just about every class thoroughly. The character retirement mechanism is brilliant to keep things moving and let you try out multiple experiences.

(2) This gets a rare endorsement of digital over physical. There’s still part of me that longs for that big box, for the tactile experience, to imagine rather than be shown the details. But why deny it: the digital implementation is fantastic. The dungeons come alive, the allies and monsters are great. Lightening the load of all the crushing, error-prone overhead on this one let me focus on gameplay and cruise through scenarios in half the time. I hesitated to award the full 10 since digital is mandatory for me. But the design still comes through. Consider it a caveat.

(3) 4-player JOTL was too much. Too many monsters and way too long. I get the extenuating circumstances with the particular needs of JOTL to get it on the shelf at Target, but it meant cramming scenarios into a printed binder and artificially creating complexity with irritating spawn points or monster powers, but either way, 2P is just so much faster and cleaner. I think 3P is the sweet spot though. Your characters have more interaction and you can really enjoy some support classes. It does mean more enemies than 2P and longer scenarios but it's still tolerable. I’d like to play with another human at some point but going solo and 2/3-handing things worked great (at least on digital).

Gloomhaven – The undisputed king of campaign-driven dungeon crawlers. You lead your mercenary through the grim streets and twisted wilderness of Gloomhaven, uncovering dark conspiracies, forging uneasy alliances, and sometimes embracing the shadows yourself. What sets this apart is the deep, card-based system — more Euro than Ameritrash — where every choice matters, and your deck is your lifeline. Tactical combat blends seamlessly with evolving personal stories and goals, and unlocking new characters feels like leveling up your own heroic saga. It’s long, it’s complex, and it demands your full attention — but the payoff is an epic adventure that sticks with you long after the last scenario ends. If you want your dungeon crawl with brains, heart, and a little bit of darkness, this is the gold standard.

- Tracking choices is hard. And even if you write down what is this scenario should lead to, you can open the scenario book and find out that it is locked by some achievement you haven't heard yet. Map serves a purpose of tracking your campaign progress but after a while you will fail to remember what place is what.
- Rules are well written but still contain many quirks. You can be certain at least some rules. Instead of expanding the FAQ, Isaac could have add some reminder text on cards to help you understand how to use them - the cards are quite big, have no art and usually there is plenty space.

Despite all that the game is really, really good.
- The combat, it's core, is fun and challenging. Choosing what cards to loose for good, predicting how will the enemies move, optimizing your moves with other players - engrossing.
- the progress really feels deserved - going forward a single level easily takes 3 or more scenarios and when you do level up it unlocks so much that it makes a difference.
- the scenarios are well thought out. Many times we would win by a hair's breadth and it was so relieving to know we do not have to replay this scenario ( because it take so much time). I actually thought that the game was too hard out of the box - until I've found out I've placed too many monsters for the first scenario for the first two attempts.

Eventually we've completed the campaign and sold it. Realistically we will never spend 60 hours on a board game campaign.

Incredible design. Although the admin and needless book keeping gets tedious after a while.

First I don't care much about the legacy elements or the story parts, but it's a great way of slowly unlocking content. It means new players have a limited amount of characters that are easier to learn while more complex ones become available later. Also the starting level of new characters increases over time, meaning even the first character you played will have new options later on that increase or change the experience when playing the character again.
Where this design choice really shows is the personal mission each character has. If your character fulfills his secret mission he retires, unlocking new content. This gives you a very specific goal you are trying to fulfill beyond completing the scenario in front of you, and adds so much to the feeling of the game.

What makes Gloomhaven so great is how ridiculously well designed it is. The difficulty is well balanced so that each map is finished just about in time before you run out of actions - and balance is great for different player counts as well. The characters are fun to play with combos and cool abilities. They play very different to each other, much more than in other similar games.
The card based based combat is awesome. First you don't draw - your cards and available actions are fully controlled by you. All your options are available as the game starts and slowly you lose cards until you are exhausted - its very clever as it adds an aspect of resource management. Your character can burn very bright for few big moves, but you have to rein her/him in to last till the end of the scenario.
Next you don't play a card - you play two cards. Each card has 2 possible actions, top and bottom. For one card you have to do the top action, for the other card the bottom action, in any order. Meaning with only 5 cards left you still have more than 20 possible combinations not to mention that cards can be used as a default attack/move action ignoring their text. On top of that you know which of the cards you might get back after this or further turns and which not, meaning you want to plan ahead for future combos. It's a brilliant system that deserves way more credit than it gets.

In contrast to this there is a damage modifier deck adding up to +/-2 to your attack (we're playing variant without miss/crit). It's a good distribution with +0 being very common, +1 or -1 less common and finally +/-2 being rare. While I dislike this (bad luck on most luck based mechanics), you mitigate this over time - permanently. First you don't roll die, you draw from a deck enforcing a certain level of distribution, second as characters level up they change the distribution of the deck removing negative cards adding positive ones. With new characters starting at higher levels you very quickly skew the deck in your favour. To give you an idea - after 3 scenarios I was level 3 with 1 perk, removing 2x -1 cards and adding 4x +1 cards to the deck. I didn't actually count the cards, but I think you start with 20. You can even add powerful bless cards to it for 1 mission by spending some gold.

This level of randomness in a coop game is fun and I wouldn't change it (coming from someone who wouldn't play the game if it had dice rolling for to hit rolls). And if you like games of chance (first go to a casino and don't ruin boardgames, but second..) you can make the deck more "chancy" by removing most +0s and adding few stronger cards to it.

Note that I find the rulebook terrible to use. The rules individually are easy to read and comprehend, but there is many of them and the structure of the rulebook is painful, so finding specific information can grind games to a halt.

TLDR summary: Absolute must-play and #1 is very deserved for its brilliant design and perfect execution.
